'''Islamic Modernism''' is a movement that has been described as "the first Muslim ideological response"<ref name="moaddel">[http://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=ZNPY3nLPRS4C&oi=fnd&pg=PP11&dq=islamic+modernism&ots=2ofzBa6vm9&sig=uvFNh124Ra96lB1_idFiDt2CvDI#PPA2,M1 Islamic modernism, nationalism, and fundamentalism By Mansoor Moaddel]</ref> to the cultural challenges which attempts to reconcile [[Islam]]ic faith with modern values regarding [[nationalism]], [[democracy]], [[civil rights]], [[rationality]], [[Egalitarianism|equality]] and [[Social progress|progress]].<ref name="EoI">[''Encyclopedia of Islam and the Muslim World'', Thompson Gale (2004) </ref> It featured a "critical reexamination of the classical conceptions and methods of jurisprudence" and a new approach to Islamic theology and Quranic exegesis.<ref name="moaddel"/>
==Overview==
Some trends in modern Islamic thought include:
* Restricting traditional Islamic law by limiting its basis to the [[Quran]] and authentic [[Sunnah]], limiting the Sunna with radical [[Hadith]] criticism.<ref>Muhammad 'Abduh, for example, said a Muslim was obliged to accept only mutawatir hadith, and was free to reject others about which he had doubts - Risalat al-Tawhid, 17th Printing, Cairo: Maktabat al-Qahira, 1379/1960, pp. 201-3; English translation by K. Cragg and I. Masa'ad, The Theology of Unity London: Allen and Unwin, 1966, pp. 155-56. Ahmad Amin, in his popular series on Islamic cultural history, cautiously suggested that there were few if any mutawatir hadith (especially, Fajr al-Islam, 10th edition Cairo: Maktabat al-Nahda al-Misriyya, 1965, p. 218; see also G. H. A. Juynboll, The Authenticity of the Tradition Literature: Discussions in Modern Egypt (Leiden: Brill, 1969), and my Faith of a Modern Muslim Intellectual, p. 113.</ref> A few, such as [[Ghulam Ahmed Pervez]] in Pakistan, go further and treat only the Quran as absolutely binding.
* A more or less radical (re)interpretation of the authoritative sources. This is particularly the case with the Quranic texts on [[polygyny]], the [[hadd]] (penal) punishments, [[jihad]], and treatment of unbelievers, which conflict with "modern" views.<ref>See Quran 4:3 on polygyny, 5:38 on cutting off the hand of the thief, 24:2-5 on whipping for fornication (the provision for stoning for adultery is in the Hadith). On jihad and the treatment of unbelievers, the difficult passages for modernists are the so-called "verses of the sword," such as 9:5 on the Arab pagans and 9:29 on the people of the Book â Shepard, W E, op cit, 1987, p. 330</ref>
* An [[apologetic]] which links aspects of the Islamic tradition with Western ideas and practices, and claims Western practices in question were originally derived from Islam.{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}} Modernist apologetic has however been severely criticized by many scholars as superficial, tendentious and even psychologically destructive, so much so that the term "apologetics" has almost become a term of abuse in the literature on modern Islam.<ref>Smith's criticism of Farid Wajdi in Islam in âModern Historyâ, pp. 139-59, and Gibb's complaint about "the intellectual confusions and the paralyzing romanticism which cloud the minds of the modernists of today" - âModern Trends in Islamâ, Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1947, pp. 105-6.</ref>
===History=== In relation to the [[Islamic Caliphate]], some Modernists argue there was no glorious history as the first three [[Caliphs]] were assassinated. Furthermore, Spain, Africa and Persia were autonomous at different points in history resulting in there being no one [[Caliphate]] state, contradicting traditional historiography which relates the [[Umayyad]], [[Abbasid]] and [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] Caliphates as maintaining general political and territorial integrity with fragmentation and divisions being the exception.{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}}
==Criticism of Modernism== {{POV-section|date=December 2008}}
Criticism of Islamic modernism comes mainly from supporters of [[Islamism]] who argue modernist thought is little more than the fusion of Western Secularism with spiritual aspects of Islam.{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}}. Other critics have described the modernist positions on politics in Islam as ideological stances.<ref>Shepard, E, âIslam and Ideology: Towards a Typologyâ, International Journal of Middle East Studies, Vol. 19, No. 3, Aug 1987, Cambridge University Press, p. 307</ref>
Critics argue politics is inherently embedded in Islam, a rejection of the secular principle, "render unto Caesar what is Caesar's". They claim that there is a consensus in Muslim political jurisprudence, philosophy and practice with regard to the Caliphate form of government with a clear structure comprising a Caliph, assistants (muâawinoon), governors (wulaat), judges (qudaat) and administrators (mudeeroon).<ref>Nabhani, T, "The Islamic Ruling System", al-Khilafah Publications</ref><ref>Mawardi, "Ahkaam al-Sultaniyyah"</ref>
It is argued that Muslim jurists have tended to work with the governments of their times. Notable examples are [[Abu Yusuf]], [[Mohammed Ibn al-Hasan]], [[Shafiâi]], [[Yahya bin Said]], [[Abu Hamid al-Ghazali]], [[Ismail bin Yasa]], [[Ibn Tulun]], [[Abu Zura]], [[Abu Hasan al-Mawardi]] and [[Tabari]].<ref>Hallaq, W, âThe Origins and Evolution of Islamic Lawâ, Cambridge University Press, 2005, pp.173-6, 182-7</ref><ref>Salahi, A, âPioneers of Islamic Scholarshipâ, The Islamic Foundation, 2006, pp. 51-2</ref> Prominent [[theologians]] would counsel the [[Caliph]] in discharging his Islamic duties, often on the request of the incumbent [[Caliph]]. Many rulers provided patronage to scholars across all disciplines, the most famous being the [[Abassids]] who funded extensive translation programmes and the building of libraries.
